question: In the narrative, how do the familial and mentorship connections—specifically, Cousin Cæsar Simon receiving his first lesson of reward for imagination from big-sis, who also raised him as the son of S. S. Simon's brother—impact the development of Cæsar Simon's character and his later relationships and actions within the interconnected Simon, Carlo, and Fairfield families?
gold_answer: Cousin Cæsar receives his first lesson of reward for imagination from big-sis, who also raises Cæsar Simon. This mentorship and familial link set the foundation for Cæsar Simon's later interactions, including his involvement in delivering important information and being part of a broader network that influences events among the Simon, Carlo, and Fairfield families.
llm_answer:
The single formative moment—when “big-sis,” the penniless washer-woman who is raising him, cuts her last loaf and spreads her last mouthful of butter on it and gives it to the dreaming child because he has said he “expected to see one of them bubbles burst into a l-o-a-f of b-r-e-a-d”—teaches Cousin Cæsar that an act of imagination can be instantly rewarded by someone who loves him. That lesson, delivered by the woman who is both foster-mother and only family, becomes the emotional template for the rest of his life: the world ought to give him what he pictures, and someone ought to pay the cost.

Because big-sis is the sister of S. S. Simon’s brother, Cæsar is born into the Simon bloodline but outside its wealth. The early indulgence from big-sis lets him grow up “too big to whip,” convinced that work is unnecessary and that someone will always rescue or feed him. When he later learns that his uncle S. S. Simon has left “one of the largest estates in Arkansas,” the childhood equation—imagination equals reward—turns into the conviction that the fortune is already his by right. The same certainty makes him detest the idea that the estate might pass to Roxie Fairfield (Roxie Daymon’s daughter), whom he regards as a “stranger.”

Thus the earliest bond with big-sis, who raised him as the orphaned son of the Simon brother, hard-wires an expectation of unearned abundance; every later relationship—his servile loyalty to Governor Mo-rock, his readiness to “break the will,” his shock at meeting Roxie Daymon’s daughter—flows from that first lesson that the world must rise to meet his visions.
